content.webTitle: Sound and fury: Macbeth, Prince Malcolm, and our unfolding political tragedy | Kristina Keneally

fields.headline: Sound and fury: Macbeth, Prince Malcolm, and our unfolding political tragedy
fields.bodyText: It is a tale told by an idiot, full of sound and fury, signifying nothing. – Macbeth Act 5 Oh, how many times has this line from Shakespeare sprung to my mind as I listened to some mock outrage played out in the theatre of our nation’s parliaments. But perhaps this line has never more aptly applied than last week during Malcolm Turnbull’s tirade against Bill Shorten. Yes, Turnbull’s attack was nothing more than sound and fury. It was quite furious, a side of the prime minister we have seen before (election night) and hear whispers about – but rarely is that fury on such public display. Turnbull’s attack was laden with personal smear and insult. It signified nothing of substance. But Macbeth’s lament is even more relevant to Turnbull. Macbeth utters these words as he realises his demise is near. He is reflecting that his great acts – namely, murdering King Duncan and taking his throne – are meaningless. His own reign, and indeed his life, is about to come to an end. In that moment, Macbeth possesses the self-awareness to see that his seizure of leadership has failed. Duncan’s son – coincidentally, for our purposes, named Malcolm – is about to storm the castle and take back the crown. Macbeth sees clearly that all he has said and done will amount to little. He seems to grasp that he was probably not suited to the (literal) cut and thrust of leadership. Life’s but a walking shadow, a poor player, that struts and frets his hour upon the stage, and then is heard no more. Turnbull may not yet possess Macbeth’s clear-eyed understanding of his fate but he is going to share it soon, and he is starting to hear the drumbeat of the advancing armies. What else can explain the sudden attack on Shorten? For the best part of the past year, even during the election campaign, Turnbull adopted a benign posture towards the Labor leader. In the adversarial, robust nature of Australian politics, Turnbull’s inattention to his opponent was weird. Perhaps Turnbull saw Shorten as unworthy of his contempt, so beneath his intellectual level and innate charm as to not merit attack. Of course, Shorten and the Labor opposition are not the only army coming for Turnbull. One Nation is making significant inroads into the Coalition base, building on the four Senate seats gained under Turnbull’s double-dissolution election. The Liberal senator Cory Bernardi is a Liberal no more, jumping ship to form a new party, Australian Conservatives. The rump of conservative MPs left – Tony Abbott, Eric Abetz and George Christensen, to name a few – are emboldened and empowered by their ability to attract media and restrict Turnbull’s choices. Newspoll is on a downward spiral, the budget deficit is on an upward spiral, and the Western Australian Liberals are preferencing One Nation above their Coalition partners, the Nationals, in the upper house in next month’s state election. Turnbull has been mocked and ridiculed by the Republican president of the United States. On top of it all, a whole host of conservative commentators – from Andrew Bolt to Peta Credlin to Judith Sloan and Rowan Dean – continually broadcast Turnbull’s failings. Shorten is just the one Turnbull can attack, and attack he did. Who can blame him for lashing out? His castle is crumbling. The Australian right is fracturing between social conservatives, ideologues, identity politicians, economic irrationalism and small-L liberalism. The times do not suit Turnbull. Like Macbeth, he lacks the personal qualities required for great leadership. Greeted like a god when he took the prime ministership, Turnbull has proven mightily mortal and flawed. Last week he took the only path left: fight, attack, try to defend. Macbeth, aware of his looming demise, clings to the belief that he is invincible and takes up arms to defend his throne. He even commits murder in his own defence. Still, for Macbeth, it is futile. He is beheaded and Prince Malcolm is restored to the throne. No doubt Turnbull would prefer to see himself as his namesake in the play – the deposed leader who, in 2015, removed the interloper Abbott and claimed the position that is his birthright. Alas, that is not where history will cast him. Instead, the only question that seems to remain: who will play Prince Malcolm in Australia’s unfolding political tragedy? Tomorrow and tomorrow and tomorrow creeps in this petty pace from day to day, to the last syllable of recorded time, and all our yesterdays have lighted fools the way to dusty death. Out, out, brief candle! We await the next act.
